entry.title: Appendix B: Post and comment classification prompts
entry.summary: For this report, Reddit posts and comments were classified using the following prompts to GPT-4.1 mini. The prompts were designed to mirror the codebooks that our research team used to create the validation datasets of human-annotated posts and comments. In the prompt templates below, italics indicate input text that varies based on the post or [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix B: Post and comment classification prompts appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Distinctive terms by topic in r/Parenting posts
entry.summary: All 29,925 Reddit posts in our dataset were classified by mentions of three topics: family finances, technology use, and division of labor. We used a pointwise mutual information (PMI) metric to identify terms that are associated with posts mentioning each topic. Distinctive terms for each topic are listed in the table below. The post Appendix A: Distinctive terms by topic in r/Parenting posts appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This report is based on two different data sources: a representative survey of U.S. parents and Reddit data from the r/Parenting subreddit. The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 171 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Primary researchers Anna Lieb, Computational Social Science AssistantAthena Chapekis, Computational Social Science AnalystSono Shah, Associate Director, Data LabsAaron Smith, Director, Data LabsSofia Conway, Qualitative Analysis InternSawyer Reed, Research Assistant Research team Devin Teehan, Former Qualitative Analysis Intern Editorial and [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How Parents Use Online Communities
entry.summary: On Reddit's largest parenting forum, around one-in-five posts mention kids' tech use. Posts often express negative emotions, but comments are overwhelmingly supportive. The post How Parents Use Online Communities appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: The best places to eat in Mississippi may be at gas stations
entry.summary:
Fratesi's Grocery has been a staple of the Leland, Mississippi, community since it opened in 1941. From Delta tamales to ‚Äúchicken on a stick‚Äù in Oxford and spicy Vietnamese seafood boils along the Gulf, here are the roadside stations that serve up a taste of the state‚Äôs culture and history.
Stop at just about any gas station in Mississippi, and you‚Äôll be greeted with a full tank and an even fuller belly.
While most would associate gas station food with rows of chips and candy bars, a wall of sodas, and the questionable hot dog rotisserie, in Mississippi, you‚Äôll be met with jars of homemade jams, pickled veg, and a fully stocked kitchen with a chef slinging out fresh, delicious, hot food to a line of customers.
‚ÄúI have long felt that you can learn a lot about a place by go‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can zapping your vagus nerve really ease anxiety?
entry.summary:
Vagus nerve stimulators deliver mild electrical pulses through the ear or neck, aiming to activate the body‚Äôs built-in ‚Äúrest and digest‚Äù system. Researchers are investigating whether they can actually reduce stress and improve sleep. Vagus nerve stimulation is a social-media sensation, promising instant stress relief. Here‚Äôs what the science really says about the body‚Äôs built-in ‚Äúchill‚Äù circuit.
Can you really calm your nervous system with a tiny jolt of electricity? That‚Äôs the promise behind a new wave of wellness gadgets designed to stimulate the vagus nerve, which helps the body regulate stress, digestion, and mood. On social media, users say they are a ‚Äúlife changer‚Äù and that daily use helps them ‚Äúsleep through the night,‚Äù and ‚Äúget out of a panic attack in 20 seconds.‚Äù
¬†Th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Making sense of the pyramids‚Äô enduring mysteries
entry.summary: So the pyramids might have been a kind of marine-industrial project, and what we now know as the sandblasted Giza plateau perhaps bordered a bustling harbor. It takes some getting used to. Those giant triangles in the desert‚Äîat once confounding to modern adults and relatable to preschoolers everywhere‚Äîhave spawned so many crazy ideas that they long ago began to seem like primeval provocations. Some of this, including the persistent notion that these are alien deposits, was owed to the implausible sourcing and transport of so much raw material, hurdles that recede after the discovery of a lost branch of the Nile. But the pyramids‚Äô final assembly instructions remain lost in the mail. We know only that they are uncannily aligned with the cardinal directions and that their bases are remarkably‚Ä¶

entry.title: Exclusive: Sperm whale speech has human-like 'vowels'
entry.summary: A group of sperm whales (Physeter macrocephalus) swims together in the Indian Ocean. For years, researchers with Project CETI have worked to decode the communication of the species. The mammals' mysterious clicks contain a stunning level of complexity, a new study shows. Humpback whales sing songs with melodies so beautiful they lulled a generation of babies to sleep and sparked a global movement to save the whales from extinction. The sounds that sperm whales produce, however, are far less musical. They emit powerful staccato clicks that call to mind a thumbnail dragging over the teeth of a metal comb, or an underwater jackhammer. But what they lack in musicality they make up for in depth. Scientists are increasingly realizing that sperm whales have one of the‚Ä¶

entry.title: 6 coastal highlights of Spain's Costa de la Luz
entry.summary:
Cape Trafalgar is famous not just as the site of the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805, but also for its lighthouse. Whether you‚Äôre cycling or riding, hiking or dining, the Costa de la Luz is awash with adventures.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
From wild Atlantic beaches to pine-clad cliffs and seafood feasts in the dunes, Spain‚Äôs luminous Costa de la Luz is a region that rewards slow discovery. Shaped by history and nature, it‚Äôs a place where tuna has been fished for millennia, wetlands echo with bird calls, and horses canter into blazing sunsets. Its contrasts are striking, its stories compelling ‚Äî and these six highlights capture the coast‚Äôs enduring allure.
For three millennia, Atlantic bluefin tuna has been fished in the bountiful wat‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN and African Union vow closer action for peace and development
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General called on Wednesday for action to prioritize Africa, urging the world not to turn its back on the continent.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòA wave of truth‚Äô: COP30 targets disinformation threat to climate action
entry.summary: Negotiators in Bel√©m, Brazil, opened COP30 with a stark warning: the race to avert catastrophic global heating is being sabotaged by a surge of climate disinformation. The falsehoods, spreading faster than ever online, threaten to derail fragile progress on climate action.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: TB cases fall for first time since pandemic
entry.summary: Tuberculosis, or TB, remains one of the world‚Äôs deadliest infectious killers, claiming over 1.2 million lives and affecting an estimated 10.7 million people last year, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: At-risk mountain vipers and iguanas, in rare company at key wildlife talks
entry.summary: Renewed efforts to protect the world‚Äôs most exotic and endangered animals and plants from illegal traders, overexploitation and extinction are set to begin at UN-partnered biodiversity talks in Uzbekistan at the end of the month.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: Migration chief hears horrific accounts of exodus from El Fasher
entry.summary: Some 90,000 people have been displaced following the fall of El Fasher in Sudan‚Äôs North Darfur - with another 50,000 fleeing violence in the Kordofans, according to the UN migration chief.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Gaza latest, Americas loses measles-free status, tornado recovery in Brazil
entry.summary: At least 600,000 litres of desperately needed diesel fuel has managed to enter the Gaza Strip in less than a week, UN aid coordinators OCHA said in an update.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukrainian civilian casualties rise 27 per cent compared to last year
entry.summary: Civilian casualties in Ukraine were 27 per cent higher from January to October 2025, compared to the same period last year, according to the latest UN human rights report on the situation in the eastern European country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Millions of lives at risk, warn UN food agencies, as hunger crisis worsens
entry.summary: The UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) and World Food Programme (WFP) warn of a major hunger emergency, with acute food insecurity set to worsen in 16 countries and territories between now and May 2026, putting millions of lives at risk.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Latest deadly shipwreck highlights need for safer migration
entry.summary: Forty-two people are missing and presumed dead following a shipwreck off Libya ‚Äì the latest fatal crossing in the Central Mediterranean, where more than 1,000 lives have been lost this year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Stand your ground: How one community in Brazil is coping with rising tides
entry.summary: For more than 40 years Ivanil lived in a house raised on stilts just 20 metres from the water‚Äôs edge, in the same community where she was born, on Maraj√≥ Island where the Amazon River meets the Atlantic Ocean in northern Brazil.

entry.title: The other side of the mountain
entry.summary: In Southwestern China, a filmmaker follows her father on a search for his childhood home, reshaped by history and time - by Aeon Video Watch on Aeon

entry.title: New Tools to Reduce the Risks for Whistleblowers

entry.title: The ultimate guide to Sonoma‚Äôs wine country
entry.summary:
Sonoma‚Äôs diverse microclimates make it ideal for growing over 60 grape varieties, establishing it as an exciting wine region in California. With bountiful organic produce, sustainable wineries and a glorious Pacific coastline, Sonoma county in northern California offers a beautiful, quieter alternative to its better-known neighbour, Napa Valley.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
An hour north of San Francisco, Sonoma‚Äôs storybook landscape unfurls: mist-draped valleys, sun-dappled meadows and miles of Pacific coastline. Quaint towns with historic facades and artisanal shops whisper of a simpler, slower-paced era. Everywhere you turn, farm-fresh produce takes centre stage, from local markets to menus that celebrate the season. Yet beneath this id‚Ä¶

entry.title: 9 ways to experience classic Tanzania
entry.summary:
Despite the harsh conditions surrounding Lake Natron, about 2.5 million lesser flamingos come have adapted to feed on the algae found in the water. Best known for one of the world‚Äôs most incredible wildlife spectacles ‚Äî the Great Migration across the Serengeti ‚Äî this East African nation offers many extraordinary travel experiences, from mountain climbs to culture-rich stays on tropical islands.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There‚Äôs much more to the central African nation than safari. Tanzania is a country that doesn‚Äôt do things by halves. The big, bold, beautiful nation lays claim to Africa‚Äôs highest mountain (Kilimanjaro) and its second-largest national park (Nyerere). It has portions of the continent‚Äôs deepest and biggest lakes (Tangan‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to hike without crowds near Grand Canyon
entry.summary:
Travelers visiting Grand Canyon National Park may want to consider visiting less-crowded places nearby, such as Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, which shares a border with the national park. Hike through secret slot canyons, spot endangered California condors, visit sacred Navajo sites, and kayak a stunning 10-mile section of the Colorado River.
In northern Arizona, near the Utah border, the community of Marble Canyon is surrounded by a distinct and stunning part of the Colorado Plateau. There are sheer, crimson-colored cliffs rising more than 3,000 feet, swirling sandstone slot canyons, and dramatic rock formations. A fraction of those who visit¬†Grand Canyon National Park¬†make it to this remote and rugged region, essentially cut off from the rest of the state by the vast cany‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here are 10 of the most beautiful castles in Germany
entry.summary:
Neuschwanstein Castle, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is a 19th-century castle that is said to have inspired Disney. There are tens of thousands of castles in Germany. Here are ten of our favorites that you can visit‚Äîor maybe even book as your very own fairy-tale wedding venue.
Germany is home to tens of thousands of castles, including one that is recognized the world over: Neuschwanstein was the inspiration for some of Disney's fairytale castles. The new National Geographic book,¬†The Traveler's Atlas of the World, includes itineraries and recommendations for seeing castles, as well as what to do in countries all over the world. Here are 10 castles to visit in Germany.
This fairy-tale palace is so exquisite it‚Äôs said to have inspired Disney theme park castles. Located sou‚Ä¶

entry.title: Heavy drinking linked to deadlier brain hemorrhages
entry.summary:
A color-enhanced, cross-sectional CT image of the brain of a patient showing a massive intracerebral hemorrhage (bleed) in the right temporal lobe. New research shows a link between heavy drinking and bigger brain bleeds. A new study found that habitual drinkers were more likely to develop earlier strokes and larger brain bleeds.
It‚Äôs long been known that heavy drinking raises blood pressure and damages the liver. But new research suggests it may also deal a devastating blow to the brain‚Äîcausing life-threatening hemorrhagic strokes.
The¬†study, published November 5 in Neurology,¬†found that people who consumed three or more alcoholic drinks a day experienced bleeding strokes inside the brain an average of 11 years earlier than light or non-drinkers‚Äîand faced worse outcomes such ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The students who developed a plan to stop Armageddon
entry.summary:
This spectacular image of comet Tempel 1 was taken 67 seconds after it obliterated NASA's Deep Impact's impactor spacecraft. In the 1960s, when the possibility of an asteroid impact alarmed the American public for the first time, MIT students drafted a blueprint for saving the Earth.
In 2021, a global survey of 10,000 young people between the ages of 16 and 25 found that 75 percent were fearful of the future. More than half believed that humanity is doomed to extinction.
There‚Äôs good reason for such pessimism. Today‚Äôs college students are growing up in an era of rising and multiplying risks to humanity. But not all of these existential risks are growing more dangerous. In fact, the ultimate risk ‚Äì that of a world-destroying comet or asteroid impact ‚Äì is now much lower than it ‚Ä¶

entry.title: World News in Brief: Refugee boat tragedy in Andaman Sea, Gaza vaccinations, farmers‚Äô lending scheme
entry.summary: At least 21 Rohingya refugees, including two teenage girls, have died after a boat carrying up to 70 people capsized in the Andaman Sea off the coasts of Malaysia and Thailand, according to UN agencies.

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa: Relief efforts intensify as damage across Caribbean grows
entry.summary: Two weeks after Hurricane Melissa tore through the Caribbean, governments and aid agencies are still struggling to reach communities left without homes, healthcare and basic services, as damage assessments in Cuba, Jamaica and Haiti continue to rise, the UN said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Tanzania: Reports of hundreds killed and detained following deadly election violence
entry.summary: Hundreds of protesters and others have been killed and an unknown number injured or detained in Tanzania following protests surrounding last month‚Äôs elections, according to reports obtained by the UN human rights office (OHCHR).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Stakes rise for South Sudan: What‚Äôs happening, and why it matters
entry.summary: South Sudan is entering a period of rising instability marked by political polarisation, renewed armed clashes, and severe humanitarian strain, senior UN officials told the Security Council on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Keeping cool on a hotter planet: COP30 pushes for sustainable cooling and AI innovation
entry.summary: As the planet heats up, so does the race for smarter, cleaner technology. At COP30 in Bel√©m, Brazil, delegates are weighing a paradox at the heart of climate innovation: how to harness powerful tools like artificial intelligence (AI) and advanced cooling systems without deepening the very crisis they aim to solve.

entry.title: International Criminal Court: Sanctions threaten global fight against impunity
entry.summary: Coercion and sanctions against the International Criminal Court (ICC) are ‚Äúassaults on the very principles of international law itself,‚Äù the President of the UN General Assembly warned on Tuesday.

entry.title: Trapped behind bars: Reforming Haiti‚Äôs broken detention system
entry.summary: Fifty-two prisoners have died in Haiti‚Äôs overcrowded prisons between July and September this year in conditions that have been described by the United Nations as ‚Äúinhuman and degrading.‚Äù

entry.title: Sudan war: Women endure starvation, rape and bombs fleeing El Fasher
entry.summary: In war-torn Sudan, rape is likely being used as a weapon of war and simply being a woman there is ‚Äúa strong predictor‚Äù of hunger, violence and death, the¬†UN‚Äôs gender equality agency warned on Tuesday.

entry.title: What is lake-effect snow?
entry.summary:
Steam is seen rising off a frozen Lake Michigan in Chicago. The Great Lakes region experiences a weather phenomenon called lake-effect snow, where cold, dry air passes over warmer lake water and forms bands of snowfall. Warmer waters are fueling stronger, snowier storms‚Äîat least for now. Here‚Äôs how scientists think this phenomenon will evolve as the planet gets hotter.
Winter weather is ransacking the Chicago metro area and parts of Indiana as the region experiences one of winter‚Äôs most brutal weather phenomena: lake-effect snow. Heavy snow covered the area Sunday night into Monday morning, with more than a foot of snow recorded by mid-Monday.
Lake-effect snow forms when warm, unfrozen lake water and cold air meet. Some of the lake water evaporates into the air, making it war‚Ä¶

entry.title: Fossil eggs reveal new way to date the Age of the Dinosaurs
entry.summary:
Scientists excavate dinosaur egg nests in Mongolia's Eastern Gobi Basin. National Geographic Explorer Lindsay Zanno and her team analyzed eggs from the region to test a new method for dating fossils. Radioactive minerals in eggshells can help scientists pinpoint a fossil‚Äôs age with stunning accuracy.
Eggs laid by dinosaurs have provided paleontologists with a new way to tell prehistoric time. By looking to radioactive minerals taken up by eggshells in the deep past, experts have uncovered a novel method to determine when those eggs were laid‚Äîone that could put ancient ecosystems on a more accurate timeline
The new research, published today in the journal Communications Earth & Environment, adds to a growing body of evidence that fossil eggshells hold mineral clues that will al‚Ä¶

entry.title: The top outdoor experiences in El Salvador
entry.summary:
Dwarfed by volcano summits ever-looming on the horizon, El Salvador‚Äôs cloud forests flutter with the flight of iridescent birds. Its verdant hills level out at laid-back, black-sand beaches that line its Pacific shore, where surfers flock to the barrelling breakers. Opportunities for adventure far outstrip this Central American country‚Äôs small stature ‚Äî despite its size, its landscape is diverse and densely packed with natural wonders.
The country‚Äôs cosmopolitan capital, San Salvador, is a convenient base for arranging adventurous excursions. From hiking up immense volcanos and swimming in the pools of hidden waterfalls, to paddling through mangrove forests brimming with wildlife and surfing world-class waves ‚Äî here are the top outdoor experiences not to be missed. Spend a day o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Brussels is the perfect European city break
entry.summary:
Brussels‚Äô skyline and Town Hall tower can be seen from the rooftop terrace of the Bourse Brussels building. It‚Äôs 30 years since daily Eurostar services began whisking visitors to Belgium‚Äôs capital ‚Äî and the city known for Tintin and beer is still full of surprises.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With the exception of the ‚ÄòMuscles from Brussels‚Äô Jean-Claude Van Damme, it‚Äôs a peculiar fact that none of the most famous Belgians are real. Tintin‚Äôs a comic book creation; Poirot an invention of Agatha Christie‚Äôs imagination; the tiny, blue Smurfs live in mushroom-shaped houses in a fictional forest. Belgium‚Äôs multilingual capital ‚Äî and the de-facto home of the EU ‚Äî is also known for its 400-year-old statue of a small boy peeing into a fountain. Le‚Ä¶

entry.title: The heroes who saved the world's last tigers
entry.summary:
This story originally published in the December 1997 issue of¬†National Geographic¬†magazine.¬†See more digitized stories from our archives here.
I first saw the tigress called Sita in 1986 in Bandhavgarh National Park in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh. She lay asleep on a hillside when the elephant I was sharing with the Indian naturalist Hashim Tyabji found her, full bellied after eating from the spotted deer that lay next to her. She was exhausted by the steady strain of having to feed and care for her first litter of three cubs, whose mewing I could just make out from still higher up the slope amid the expectant cawing of crows that teetered in the branches of the surrounding trees.¬†
We were just 30 feet or so from the tigress, close enough to hear her steady, sonor‚Ä¶

entry.title: The first underwater photos reveal the ocean floor in full color
entry.summary:
Fish swim over a small head of brain coral and before massive Orbicella heads in one of the coral stacks, where small fish swarm during daylight hours only. Capturing the first underwater color photographs was no mean feat and involved powerful explosives as well as hours and hours of waiting.
This story originally published in the January 1927 issue of¬†National Geographic¬†magazine.¬†See more digitized stories from our archives here. The following illustrations are the first published natural color photographs made beneath the surface of the sea. They represent many weeks and months of experimentation by Dr. W. H. Longley, noted ichthyologist, of Goucher College, and Charles Martin, of the photographic laboratories of the National Geographic Society.¬†

author.name: National Geographic Staff, W. H. Longley, Charles Martin

entry.title: Why the mystery of the Edmund Fitzgerald endures
entry.summary: The S.S. Edmund Fitzgerald battles rough waters on her fateful voyage on Lake Superior in the artist David Conklin's painting, "Every Man Knew," commissioned to commemorate the anniversary of the tragic shipwreck. The Great Lakes freighter was one of the most technologically advanced of its time when it wrecked in Lake Superior 50 years ago. What went wrong? The good ship and crew were in peril. A savage storm was hurling hurricane-force winds, 35-foot waves, and blinding blasts of snow at the large freighter. Already reporting a ‚Äúbad list‚Äù with no radar and damaged ballast vents, it was taking on water and making slow progress battling its way across Lake Superior on November 10, 1975. Still, the vessel‚Äôs skipper, Ernest M. McSorley‚Äîconsidered one of the best on the Gr‚Ä¶

entry.title: What it really took to become an astronaut during the Space Race
entry.summary:
This story originally published in the January 1965 issue of¬†National Geographic¬†magazine.¬†See more digitized stories from our archives here.
This is the year of the Gemini.¬†
Before 1965 is many months old, a powerful Titan II rocket will blast off from Cape Kennedy, carrying two American astronauts aboard a spacecraft called Gemini‚Äîafter the twins of the zodiac. For more than two years these men and their fellow astronauts have prepared themselves for Project Gemini and the epochal lunar voyages that will follow. They have pursued a unique training curriculum, and their classrooms lie scattered throughout the country.¬†
They have attended hundreds of lectures, pored over thousands of documents, and sat through countless technical meetings.¬†
They have conditioned their ‚Ä¶

entry.title: All about Evia, a stunning Greek island with few crowds
entry.summary:
Evia is the second-largest island in Greece, after Crete. Despite its size and proximity to the busy Greek capital, Evia is one of the least-known Greek islands, with healing baths, Venetian castles, and gorgeous scenery.
In Evia‚Äôs sylvan north, peaks clad with bright green pine trees soar above beaches where the water glows with emerald intensity. To the south, there are coves lapped by aquamarine seas. Can it sometimes take the pluck of a pirate to find them? Yes, but travelers undeterred by narrow roads and switchback curves will be richly rewarded.
‚ÄúEvia offers an authentic slice of Greece that feels both timeless and undiscovered. Just a short drive or ferry from Athens, it‚Äôs a land of lush mountains, thermal springs, unspoiled beaches, and charming villages where traditi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Norway should be your next family destination
entry.summary:
The Fl√•m Railway passes peaks, farms and waterfalls, making for a varied and exciting train journey for all ages. A natural playground, the fjord district is magical for families in winter. Visit now to catch the end of 2025‚Äôs strong aurora cycle.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With an abundance of fjords and mountains reachable by train, boat and on foot, outdoorsy families will find much to enjoy in this Nordic country‚Äôs western region ‚Äî billed as ‚ÄòNorway in a nutshell‚Äô. Its superlative landscapes are ultra-accessible year-round and completely transformed by the seasons ‚Äî visit in winter for snow and the Northern Lights, or summer for wild swims and glacier hikes.
Norway‚Äôs second largest city is the gateway to its fabled fjords. Str‚Ä¶

entry.title: Fossil eggs reveal new way to date the Age of the Dinosaurs
entry.summary:
Scientists excavate dinosaur egg nests in Mongolia's Eastern Gobi Basin. National Geographic Explorer Lindsay Zanno and her team analyzed eggs from the region to test a new method for dating fossils. Radioactive minerals in eggshells can help scientists pinpoint a fossil‚Äôs age with stunning accuracy.
Eggs laid by dinosaurs have provided paleontologists with a new way to tell prehistoric time. By looking to radioactive minerals taken up by eggshells in the deep past, experts have uncovered a novel method to determine when those eggs were laid‚Äîone that could put ancient ecosystems on a more accurate timeline
The new research, published today in the journal Communications Earth & Environment, adds to a growing body of evidence that fossil eggshells hold mineral clues that will al‚Ä¶

entry.title: Discover the wild side of Dubai with these thrilling adventures
entry.summary:
From vertical-acceleration roller coasters to skydives over manmade wonders, Dubai is awash with thrilling adventures. Whether you‚Äôre heading for its desert, city, beaches or extraordinary artificial islands, the Gulf region‚Äôs most popular stopover is packed with pulse-quickening pursuits to spice up any fly-and-flop. Here are half a dozen to get you started.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Dubai has never been somewhere that does things half-heartedly. Highest, longest, deepest ‚Äî¬†the superlatives are pursued with a breathless urgency, creating the framework for what‚Äôs fast emerging as one of the world‚Äôs great playgrounds for thrill-seekers. entry.title: Safeguarding clean water access as climate threats rise
entry.summary: As health emergencies multiply linked to the climate crisis, governments are joining forces with the UN to protect access to clean water, while data indicates that 118 million people in Europe alone live near healthcare facilities lacking basic sanitation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How farms are spearheading a Northern Irish food revolution
entry.summary:
The Titanic Museum and Belfast Harbour are some of the county's major draws. In the backcountry around Belfast and the Causeway Coast, Northern Irish producers are bringing new life to old farms and creating community hubs that showcase the region‚Äôs rich artisan food scene.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs 11am and I‚Äôm having coffee. But as this is a ‚ÄòBelfast coffee‚Äô, it‚Äôs a cream-topped cold brew laced with a shot of poit√≠n, served at the capital city‚Äôs snug-boothed 19th-century Garrick pub. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the sort of thing you used to get from your backcountry man,‚Äù says my jovial guide, Ali McDevitt, brushing cream from his whiskers. Ireland‚Äôs moonshine, poit√≠n, was outlawed in the 1600s, but people continued to make the unaged spirit at home ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why you should visit Spain‚Äôs lesser-known Costa de la Luz
entry.summary:
Vejer de la Frontera in Costa de la Luz is particularly striking at sunset, with sunlight glinting off its whitewashed houses. Forget what you think you know about the built-up Spanish Costas. The aptly named Costa de la Luz ‚Äî or ‚ÄòCoast of Light‚Äô ‚Äî is a quiet stretch along Andaluc√≠a's lesser-visited Atlantic seaboard, where rolling dunes meet pine forests and timeworn towns bask in the sun. Explore its natural parks and windswept beaches, bedding down in exclusive retreats along the way.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The coastal plain far below is enveloped in a shadowy slumber as dawn strikes the hilltop town of Vejer de la Frontera. The first rays of the day glance off the tiled fountain in Plaza de Espa√±a and provoke the sparrows in the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: COP30 kicks off with urgent call to deliver on climate promises and scale up finance
entry.summary: Thousands of diplomats and climate experts are heading to Bel√©m, in Brazil‚Äôs Amazon, for COP30 ‚Äì the latest round of UN climate talks. Their task couldn‚Äôt be clearer: turn promises into action and agree on tougher plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions.

entry.title: James Watson dies at 97
entry.summary:
James Watson, the American 1962¬†Nobel Prize‚Äîwinning molecular biologist whose co-discovery of the double-helix structure of DNA helped make possible the mapping of the human genome, has died at age 97.
Often celebrated as a pioneer of genetics, allegations of uncredited work and discriminatory and inflammatory remarks cast a shadow over his legacy. James Watson (left) and Francis Crick (right) with their model of part of a DNA molecule in the Cavendish Laboratory at the University of Cambridge, UK, in May of 1953. Watson and Crick met at Cambridge in 1951 and are credited as the discoverers of the structure of DNA. Watson, Crick, and Maurice Wilkins shared the 1962 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine. Francis Crick(left) and James Watson (right) shortly after working out the‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Shanghai, China's rapidly transforming megacity
entry.summary:
Penicillin bar on Nanchang Road makes inventive cocktails using recycled waste ingredients. From xiaolongbao dumpling kiosks to riverside beer emporiums and glamorous rooftop cocktail bars, this Chinese megacity offers travellers 24/7 entertainment.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Cut a dash through this Chinese megacity from the sycamore-shaded, heritage shopping streets of the former French Concession to the high-wattage urban wonderland of the Bund. Locals here work hard and play harder, so the energy is intense ‚Äî and the people-watching is second to none.
Early birds get first crack at jianbing, the savoury crepes made with spring onions or chilli sauce at kiosks around town. Stroll along Changle Road in the former French Concessio‚Ä¶

entry.title: She‚Äôs 86. This is her 1000th skydive. Here‚Äôs how she stays young.
entry.summary:
86-year-old Kim Knor completes her 1,000th jump in New Wales, Florida, alongside her two daughters. Knor was a member of the first U.S. Women‚Äôs Parachute Team in 1962. After taking a few decades off to raise her family, she has made it a mission to hit this milestone‚Äîearning the nickname the "skydiving grandma." Kim Knor has the kind of biography Hollywood blockbusters are made of‚Äîand has just notched a new milestone in her quest to keep living life to the fullest.
To many, she‚Äôs known as the ‚Äúskydiving grandma.‚Äù And on Thursday, November 6, 2025, Kim Knor, also joined the ranks of those who have earned the United States Parachute Association Gold Wings Award for making 1000 jumps.¬†
This 86-year-old powerhouse has been traveling the country in her 21-foot Roadtrek motor home i‚Ä¶

entry.title: Rats wage war on bats in stunning new footage
entry.summary:
A rat attacks a bat as it flies by in this still image from a video that researchers captured. New videos reveal the surprising dynamics of bat-rat relationships‚Äîand suggest how human activity is fueling these interspecies conflicts.
In a dark cave in northern Germany, an invasive brown rat stands upright, balancing with its tail. Suddenly it reaches into the night sky, plucks a bat from the air, and crunches down on it.¬†
At first,¬†Mirjam Kn√∂rnschild¬†was shocked by the scene, captured with infrared surveillance video as part of her research. Kn√∂rnschild, head of the Behavioral Ecology and Bioacoustics Lab at the Museum of Natural History in Berlin, thought it could be an isolated incident‚Äîuntil her investigation at another German bat cave turned up more macabre evidence.¬† ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What to do in Gouda‚Äîand where to eat the best cheese
entry.summary:
Today, the Goudse Waag is home to the Cheese and Crafts Museum in Gouda, Holland. Here‚Äôs everywhere you should buy, taste, and learn about cheese in this historic small town in the Netherlands.
A medieval battle in Holland forever changed the cheese world as know it: Which city would be named the trading center for Stolse, what we know now as Gouda.
Gouda is and was made at dairy farms all throughout South Holland, so any city in the area could have been its trading center. Until 1412, Gouda cheese was called Stolkse (sweet milk) cheese and sold in the town of Stolwijk before moving to Schoonhoven.
Around 1540, the city of Gouda won the official cheese market title that it still holds today. Centuries later, cows still live in the lush meadows surrounding Gouda in the Che‚Ä¶

entry.title: These towns in Nashville's backyard are luring travelers
entry.summary:
Travelers looking to explore beyond Nashville, Tennessee, should consider nearby small towns: Franklin and Leiper‚Äôs Fork. Even country music stars are catching on to the appeal of Leiper‚Äôs Fork and Franklin, with their intimate venues, rolling hills, and front-porch communities.
Twenty miles south of Nashville‚Äôs neon signs, two Tennessee towns have been quietly attracting celebrities and country music stars like Chris Stapleton and Carrie Underwood. Franklin charms with its 19th-century downtown dotted with Southern boutiques, sophisticated dining, and Civil War sites. Nine miles west, the village of Leiper‚Äôs Fork landed on the National Register of Historic Places for its ‚Äúfolk vernacular‚Äù architecture, which includes simple structures authentic to this rural region.¬†
This sma‚Ä¶

entry.title: The art at these hotels rivals the world‚Äôs best museums
entry.summary:
Located in the heart of ancient Athens, The Dolli overlooks the Roman Agora. Enjoy Picasso over morning coffee, Dali over dinner, or take a garden stroll past a Henry Moore sculpture in one of these curated stays.
For anyone who‚Äôs ever felt disappointed after standing in a long museum queue only to peer over a sea of heads at a famous painting, here‚Äôs a bit of good news: A growing number of hotels and resorts around the world have begun showcasing world-class art collections without the lines or velvet ropes.
Guests or afternoon visitors can book a guided tour, scan QR codes to learn more about a piece, attend rotating exhibit openings, or just have a coffee and gaze at a favorite painting, says Kelly Cahn, a New York-based art advisor and appraiser who has worked with hotels.‚Ä¶

entry.title: Medieval nostalgia is everywhere right now
entry.summary:
In 2024, Gen Z pop star Chappell Roan capped off her meteoric rise to fame with an MTV Video Music Awards performance of her hit single ‚ÄúGood Luck, Babe.‚Äù Equal parts playful and camp, Roan wore a suit of chainmail and gleaming plate armor and fired a crossbow to ignite a pyrotechnic display in a backdrop dominated by a digitally rendered castle. There was little in the song itself to prompt such iconography: the catchy pop hit is a sarcastic kiss-off from one woman to another who just can‚Äôt admit their romantic relationship.¬†
But Roan was paying homage to the long history of Joan of Arc, the patron saint of France, who¬†has become¬†a¬†modern-day¬†queer icon for transgressing gender norms when she took¬†up arms to fight on her country‚Äôs behalf. Roan was drawing on the resonance between the‚Ä¶

entry.title: The mystery woman at the heart of Beethoven‚Äôs secret love affair
entry.summary:
Ludwig van Beethoven appeared to be as unsuccessful in love as he was successful in music.
When the celebrated composer died on March 26, 1827, he left no widow to mourn him‚Äîjust an adoring public who lined the streets to catch a glimpse of his funeral procession.
But when Beethoven‚Äôs secretary Anton Schindler went through his late employer‚Äôs desk, he made a discovery that kickstarted one of music history‚Äôs most romantic mysteries.
Inside the desk was a yearning, passionate, and lyrical love letter that Beethoven seemed to have never sent. Beethoven did not name his intended recipient. Instead, he referred to her as his ‚ÄúImmortal Beloved.‚Äù ‚ÄúI can live only wholly with you or not at all,‚Äù he wrote, ‚Äúyes, I am resolved to wander so long away from you until I can fly to your ar‚Ä¶

entry.title: How one torpedo sank the mighty Lusitania
entry.summary:
Built between 1904 and 1906, R.M.S. Lusitania measured a whopping 787 feet in length and could accommodate over 2,000 passengers and 800 crew members. It soon became the flagship of its operator, the Cunard Line, and for a time was distinguished as being the largest passenger ship in the world. Both the vessel‚Äôs luxurious design and fate are often compared to those of R.M.S. Titanic, launched in 1912 by Cunard‚Äôs main rival, the White Star Line. Despite their grandeur, both ships met tragic ends, though under markedly different circumstances. While the Titanic sank after hitting an iceberg in 1912, the Lusitania was torpedoed by a German U-boat during the First World War.
Since the onset of WWI in 1914, Germany had faced a comprehensive naval blockade imposed by the British Navy that‚Ä¶

Whether you're looking for towering rock formations, reliable wildlife sightings or just sun, sea and silence, there‚Äôs a stretch of Portuguese sand for you. Head south to the Algarve for a smuggler‚Äôs former haunt, or visit the west coast for Jurassic prints embedded into the cliffs ‚Äì these are some of the best crowd-free beaches.
Best for: spotting eagles and dolphins Lisbon isn‚Äôt far from Arr√°bida Natural Park, but you‚Äôd never guess. With secluded coves and turquoise bays strung between forested hills, this nature park is home to some of Europe‚Äôs most ravishing beaches. One of the loveliest is this crescent of creamy sand. entry.title: The fish crime detectives who protected the seas
entry.summary:
Indonesia routinely blew up vessels caught illegally fishing in their waters, like this one in 2017. Indonesia is particularly vulnerable to poachers who threaten their fishing stock and the health of the world‚Äôs oceans. The world needed a team of international police dedicated to fighting illegal fishing. Now, the group's gone quiet.
In the rough waves of the South Atlantic in February 2016, an Argentine coast guard ship approached a squid-jigging vessel illegally fishing inside the nation‚Äôs territorial waters. As the Argentines approached, the boat winched its equipment aboard and quickly fled north. The Argentines ordered the boat to stop and then fired a warning shot, but it escaped across the watery border with Uruguay and headed into international waters. Before it disappeare‚Ä¶

entry.title: These overlooked muscles are the key to aging well
entry.summary:
Exercises like the plank train the body‚Äôs full core‚Äîthe network of muscles that protect the spine, support balance, and keep you moving strong for life. From the diaphragm to the pelvic floor, scientists say improving your core strength can protect your spine and help you move with ease into older age.
‚ÄúSix-pack‚Äù abs might look like a sign of fitness, but they reveal surprisingly little about your health. The true secret to healthy aging lies not in visible abdominal muscles, but in the intricate network of muscles that make up your core.
These deeper core muscles stabilize your spine, protect your back, and power almost every movement you make. Yet training with standard moves like crunches for the sake of visible abs can do more harm than good, says Ben Yamuder, an exercise ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How one catastrophic shipwreck sank a medieval dynasty
entry.summary:
King Henry I's only legitimate heir, William Adelin, orders rowers to turn back and save his sister, the Countess of Perche, after the White Ship hit a rock in the Seine estuary. William died as the boat sunk due to the numbers struggling for survival. When a royal vessel sank of the coast of Normandy in 1120, it not only claimed hundreds of lives but also set off a succession crisis that changed England forever.
It should have been a¬†fairly routine¬†English Channel crossing for the boisterous and boozy crowd of young nobles aboard the White Ship‚Äîa party that included William Adelin, sole legitimate male heir to King Henry I of England.
Only it all went horribly wrong as the ship embarked from¬†Barfleur, in present day France, on November 25, 1120. The crew rowed right onto ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What it's like to climb Tanzania's Mount Kilimanjaro
entry.summary:
Trekking up the lower slopes of Kilimanjaro is an adventure that takes hikers to the highest peak of the continent. Kilimanjaro is a tantalising prospect: an enormous, continent-topping high that even ordinary hikers can reach once steeled to the task.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Terror and awe. That‚Äôs how I feel on first glimpsing Africa‚Äôs highest mountain. It fills the aircraft window, an incredible hulk of a thing. A brooding inevitability. It takes an age to fly past. Has my fear slowed time or is it really that big? When the massive massif is finally out of sight, it‚Äôs still all I can see in my head, all I can think about.
I‚Äôm flying into Tanzania‚Äôs Kilimanjaro Airport to climb that very peak, a 19,340ft behemoth that looms larg‚Ä¶

entry.title: The best coastal road trip you‚Äôve never heard of
entry.summary:
Cave Point County Park is home to underwater caves and incredible sunrises. The ‚ÄúCape Cod of the Midwest‚Äù is filled with memorable towns, delightful quirks, and incredible scenery. So why have so many people never heard of it? 
Door County, Wisconsin, is one of those blindsiding destinations that feels surprisingly hidden in plain sight; the kind of place where stunned travelers wonder how they had never heard of it before. The "Cape Cod of the Midwest" is more than just legendary Lake Michigan beachfronts¬†and¬†four vibrant seasons.
The¬†Door¬†Peninsula is also filled with unique towns and offbeat attractions, making it perfect for aimless road trips where itineraries are best kept minimal.
(Why Oklahoma‚Äôs Route 66 is the ultimate American road trip for 2026)

entry.title: Farmers in Brazil are restoring biodiversity to grow resilient crops
entry.summary: Brazil is one of Earth‚Äôs ground zeroes for climate change. It‚Äôs home to the Amazon, the world‚Äôs largest and most diverse tropical rainforest, which scientists have called the ‚Äúlungs of the planet‚Äù because it absorbs and stores global carbon emissions. But alarming amounts of the Amazon have been cleared and deforested over the last decades to make room for agriculture, exacerbating climate change. In a cyclical pattern, the agricultural landscape in Brazil, the world‚Äôs largest producer of staple crops, including soybeans and corn, is becoming increasingly challenged due to the impacts of a changing climate. This is especially true in the Cerrado region, which borders the Amazon and produces nearly half of the country‚Äôs agricultural products. Here, rainy seasons are beginning later and dry ‚Ä¶

entry.summary: As part of a survey of 8,750 U.S. adults aimed at understanding how Americans are thinking about and experiencing aging, we asked 2,582 Americans ages 65 and older the following question: ‚ÄúBased on your own experiences, what advice would you give to younger people to help them prepare for getting older?‚Äù Respondents answered this question [‚Ä¶] The post Advice on aging from older Americans appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How Americans are feeling about their finances as they age
entry.summary: Amid a dwindling Social Security retirement trust and increased national life expectancy, many Americans are uncertain about their financial future. Four-in-ten U.S. adults say they aren‚Äôt confident they‚Äôll have enough income and assets to last throughout their retirement years or say they won‚Äôt be able to retire at all. entry.title: Aging well: How income and health shape the experiences of older Americans
entry.summary: About one-in-five adults in the U.S. today (18%) are ages 65 and older. To understand how these older Americans are aging and the factors associated with aging well, we asked them a series of questions about how things are going in their lives and how they spend their time. entry.title: Doha: World Summit ends with renewed pledge to leave no one behind
entry.summary: The Second World Summit for Social Development wrapped up on Thursday with nations warning that global progress on poverty and inequality will stall unless countries move faster from promises to implementation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Grandi calls for greater refugee protection and funding
entry.summary: The UN High Commissioner for Refugees appealed on Thursday for more solutions to address forced displacement in his final address to the General Assembly.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council lifts terror-related sanctions on Syrian President
entry.summary: The Security Council on Thursday adopted a resolution to remove Syria‚Äôs transitional President Ahmed al-Sharaa and Interior Minister Anas Khattab from sanctions measures targeting members and supporters of terrorist groups ISIL and Al-Qaida.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nearly a third of Jamaica‚Äôs annual wealth wiped out by Hurricane Melissa
entry.summary: Around 1.5 million Jamaicans have been impacted by Hurricane Melissa ‚Äì the worst climate disaster in the Caribbean nation‚Äôs history, said the top UN development official in the region on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Genocide prevention expert raises alarm over alleged Sudan atrocity crimes
entry.summary: The UN Special Adviser on genocide prevention has raised concerns over widespread allegations of war crimes committed in Sudan‚Äôs El Fasher last month, and plans to meet his African Union counterpart on Friday to discuss a coordinated response.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israel has rejected over 100 aid requests since Gaza ceasefire, UN says
entry.summary: The United Nations said on Thursday that Israeli authorities have rejected more than 100 requests to bring relief materials into Gaza since the ceasefire began nearly a month ago.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Battlefields to wastelands: UN warns conflicts are destroying ecosystems worldwide
entry.summary: From Gaza to Ukraine and beyond, war has caused widespread death and destruction, but it has also devastated natural resources such as water systems, farmland and forests.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New Brazil-led fund aims to put forest protection at the heart of climate action
entry.summary: Tropical forests, vital allies in the fight against climate breakdown, are vanishing at an alarming rate. On Thursday, in a bid to help reverse this trend, Brazil launched a new initiative at a summit of world leaders in Bel√©m, the gateway to the Amazon.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief urges world leaders to drive down global warming
entry.summary: As world leaders gather in Brazil for the COP30 climate summit, UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres on Thursday called for urgent action to drive down global temperatures and keep the 1.5¬∞C goal within reach.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Doha summit ends with call to turn social pledges into action
entry.summary: The Second World Summit for Social Development concluded in Doha on Thursday with calls for countries to move swiftly from commitments to implementation, ensuring that the Doha Political Declaration delivers measurable progress on poverty reduction, decent work and social inclusion.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Afghanistan: Opium cultivation drops sharply, but regional trafficking rises
entry.summary: Opium poppy cultivation in Afghanistan has fallen by 20 per cent compared to last year, continuing a dramatic decline since the introduction of a nationwide ban under the Taliban in 2022 ‚Äì but synthetic drugs and shifting trafficking routes are posing new challenges.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Voices of Myanmar
entry.summary: Citizens of Myanmar describe what daily life is like in their isolated, war-torn nation - by Aeon Video Watch on Aeon

entry.title: Are you Confusedocene?

entry.title: The science of why your body resists weight loss
entry.summary:
Our bodies evolved to survive famine, not dieting. Researchers are decoding how metabolism, hunger, and hormones conspire to make keeping weight off so difficult. Research shows the battle to keep weight off isn‚Äôt about willpower‚Äîit‚Äôs biology. Here‚Äôs how scientists say we can work with our bodies, not against them.
Losing weight is hard. More than half of Americans want to do so, but keeping it off is even harder. Research shows that 80 to 95 percent of people who lose weight regain it within three to five years, according to data from the National Institutes of Health and the Obesity Society.
Scientists say that‚Äôs not a failure of willpower. Hormones, genetics, and even evolution push the body to fight back‚Äîdriving hunger up, slowing metabolism, and urging the pounds to retur‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Sicily has celebrated its diversity through the centuries
entry.summary:
Sicily is said to be the 'Gates of Europe', where stories of immigration shape the island's history and present. A journey across Sicily reveals the essence of an island shaped by outsiders, where successive waves of immigration over the centuries have created a unique cultural identity.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Dust swirls in a quiet kasbah, stirred by the sirocco ‚Äî the desert wind that carries soft Saharan sand across the Mediterranean Sea, its red grains falling in a blood rain. In the fortified central quarter, a shutter is brightly painted with the hamsa, the symbol of an open palm inset with a blue iris, believed across North Africa to deter the evil eye. A¬†woman in a slate-grey headscarf and abaya robe-dress sweeps past, offerin‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to see the northern lights in Alaska
entry.summary:
Travelers who want to experience the Northern Lights firsthand should consider visiting Alaska, such as Arctic Hive, a remote wilderness retreat center in the Brooks Range. America‚Äôs northernmost state is the perfect front-row seat to the aurora borealis‚Äîand this winter will be an extra special time to see it.
Much of America‚Äôs northernmost state,¬†Alaska, lies in the auroral oval, a donut-shaped region of light activity above Earth‚Äôs geomagnetic North and South Poles. The green and violet ribbons delight travelers during any Alaska aurora season‚Äîbut this winter could be extra special. That‚Äôs because the sun,¬†which triggers the spectacle, is in its roughly 11-year peak of activity.
‚ÄúYou can have aurora every single night in some capacity,‚Äù says¬†Vince Ledvina, a professional aur‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Grand Ole Opry enters its next century
entry.summary:
Country singers on stage at the Grand Ole Opry celebrating the show's 100th anniversary. Opry staple Vince Gill sits on the left playing his guitar. ‚ÄúPeople want to paint [the Opry] as a closed shop," Gill told National Geographic, "but it‚Äôs not the conservative flagship it‚Äôs known to be.‚Äù We went behind the scenes at the world's oldest radio show to understand how it endured 100 years‚Äîand why it might last 100 more.
Hours before the Grand Ole Opry launched its Holy Saturday broadcast earlier this year, dozens of country music fans had already gathered in the pollen-covered courtyard outside. A high-school orchestra played nearby as families, double dates, exhausted tourists, cowgirl-booted bachelorette parties, the full Nashville ecosystem, all waited on stone benches as the oldes‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here are 6 amazing ancient tattoos‚Äîand the stories behind them
entry.summary:
This mummy, held at the Museo Maria Reiche in Nazca, Peru, likely belonged to a male who lived 500 to 750 years ago in the lower Nazca River Valley and who may have played an important role in agriculture and fertility rites. As researchers discover overlooked tattoos on mummies from around the world, it's prompting new insights about some of the world's oldest ink.
It took well over a century for archaeologists to start taking ancient tattoos seriously, with old colonialist attitudes and more contemporary stigmas steering scholars away. What‚Äôs more, ancient tattoos can be difficult to study: Tattooing tools are tricky to identify in the archaeological record, and only rarely is ink well enough preserved on mummies to be visible with the naked eye.
But these days, new attitude‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Center‚Äôs Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about our international survey methodology and [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Moira Fagan, Research AssociateKirsten Lesage, Research AssociateWilliam Miner, Research AnalystAndrew Prozorovsky, Research Assistant Julia Armeli, Research AssistantDorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherJanell Fetterolf, Senior [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix: Political categorization
entry.summary: For this analysis, we grouped people into two political categories: those who support the governing political party (or parties) in their country, and those who do not. These categories were coded based on the party or parties in power at the time the survey was fielded and on respondents‚Äô answers to a question asking which [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix: Political categorization appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix: Political categorization
entry.summary: For this analysis, we grouped people into two political categories: those who support the governing political party (or parties) in their country, and those who do not. These categories were coded based on the party or parties in power at the time the survey was fielded and on respondents‚Äô answers to a question asking which [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix: Political categorization appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Dealing with climate change
entry.summary: Majorities in nine middle income countries are willing to make lifestyle changes to curb the effects of climate change ‚Äì younger adults especially so. The post 2. Dealing with climate change appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Impact of climate change
entry.summary: A 74% median across nine middle-income countries say global climate change is affecting their area, with droughts or water shortages a top concern. The post 1. Impact of climate change appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: People in Middle-Income Countries Say Climate Change Is Affecting Their Community
entry.summary: Large majorities in nine middle-income countries say global climate change is affecting their community. About half or more in Argentina, Brazil and Mexico see a great deal of impact. The post People in Middle-Income Countries Say Climate Change Is Affecting Their Community appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Doha: World Summit‚Äôs second day highlights urgency of investing in people and peace
entry.summary: As the Second World Summit for Social Development continued in Doha on Wednesday, governments warned that global progress risks stalling unless social protection, equality and peace are prioritised ‚Äì and backed with political and financial commitment.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Doha Social Summit: Businesses, civil society walk side by side for fairer futures
entry.summary: Civil society networks and private sector leaders crossed paths in the buzzing corridors of the Qatar National Convention Centre, a reminder that social development is not just debated in meetings rooms ‚Äì it touches jobs, families and futures.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war and political uncertainty block progress on Abyei peace talks
entry.summary: The UN is ready to support Sudan and South Sudan in resuming talks on the disputed Abyei border region, the Security Council heard on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan crisis: UN agencies race to aid civilians as violence engulfs El Fasher
entry.summary: UN agencies are stepping up relief operations to help civilians fleeing the escalating violence in Sudan‚Äôs North Darfur state, where fighting has triggered widespread abuses and mass displacement, Deputy UN Spokesperson Farhan Haq told reporters in New York on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa: UN launches $74 million response for 2.2 million in Cuba
entry.summary: Around 2.2 million Cubans remain in dire need of assistance across the eastern provinces of Granma, Santiago de Cuba, Holguin, and Guantanamo as the after effects of Hurricane Mellisa continue, UN aid workers said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Famine alert for South Sudan, tsunami readiness, peacekeepers flag activity along Lebanon ‚Äòblue line‚Äô
entry.summary: To South Sudan, where aid teams warn that an already severe food and nutrition crisis could get worse without urgent humanitarian relief.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Not just dreams, but rights: Social justice in focus at Doha summit
entry.summary: The push to put social justice at the heart of global policymaking took centre stage at the Second World Summit for Social Development on Wednesday, as leaders gathered for a high-level forum to drive coordinated action in delivering the newly adopted Doha Political Declaration.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Catch-up immunization campaign ‚Äòa lifeline‚Äô for Gaza‚Äôs children
entry.summary: A campaign for routine immunization, nutrition, and growth monitoring will be launched in the Gaza Strip this week with the goal of reaching 44,000 children cut off from essential life-saving services due to the devastating conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Mind over machine: UN urges ethical guardrails for brain tech revolution
entry.summary: As wearable devices begin to tap into our mental states, UN experts warn that without ethical safeguards, the right to freedom of thought could be the latest casualty of unchecked innovation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World‚Äôs forests at serious risk from warming planet, fires and pests: UNECE
entry.summary: Decades of progress in protecting the planet‚Äôs carbon dioxide-busting forests are at risk as the climate crisis continues to accelerate, UN forestry experts said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Between moon tides
entry.summary: How a dedicated team of volunteers in Rhode Island hack nature to find new ways to protect vulnerable sparrow hatchlings - by Aeon Video Watch on Aeon

entry.title: Meet Antarctica's penguins with an ornithologist
entry.summary:
In Antarctica, the weather can flip faster than almost anywhere on Earth ‚Äî it‚Äôs not unusual for skies to be clear one minute and a blizzard to blow in the next. Step out of a helicopter onto a never-before-seen island in Antarctica‚Äôs distant south during this expert-led tour around endless icebergs, frozen cliffs and mercurial glaciers.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
For the explorer Ernest Shackleton, it was the glory of reaching the South Pole that brought him to Antarctica. For polar polymath Fabrice Genevois, it was something far less dangerous: penguins.
And so, 150 miles south of the Antarctic Circle, as we land on the shore of Red Rock Ridge, Fabrice announces it‚Äôs time to get obsessed with the flightless birds ourselves. ‚ÄúKeep q‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Men and Women Spend Their Days
entry.summary: Women and men tend to spend their days differently in the United States. Varying responsibilities and priorities will do that. Tags: time use

entry.title: Why are Alaska‚Äôs rivers turning bright orange?
entry.summary:
Tukpahlearick Creek is one of many rivers and creeks in remote Alaska that has recently turned a bright orange. The dramatic shift is a warning sign‚Äîand scientists say the changes that aren't yet visible to the naked eye are just as troubling.
In the summer of 2019, ecologist Patrick Sullivan and a Super Cub plane pilot navigated over the narrow valleys of the Brooks Range in northern Alaska, winding toward the remote headwaters of the Salmon River. Sullivan was studying the slow advance of trees into what had been tundra, a sign of the rapidly changing climate, but soon discovered something far more surprising.
Sullivan was expecting a clear, cold river artery with blue-green pools, and had even brought his fishing rod. So he was shocked to see turbid water and banks stained‚Ä¶

entry.title: I set out to see the Serengeti's Great Migration‚Äîhere's what happened
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a mathematical calculation,‚Äù says my seasoned guide Allan Dawson, his brow furrowing as he smooths out a giant battered map of migration patterns over the dinner table. A bite-sized pakora in one hand, he points with the other to where we are in the far northwestern corner of Tanzania, just below the border with Kenya‚Äôs Maasai Mara. And then his finger moves south, down below the Mara River ‚Äî famed for its dramatic animal river crossings ‚Äî and down further still, to the central Serengeti. It‚Äôs here, he says, that the herds of wildebeest and zebras have stopped.
It‚Äôs the first day of a trip to witness the Great Migration, in which the herds make their annual pilgrimage north across the 5,791sq-mile Serenge‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Scottish trail is the best way to explore the Highlands
entry.summary:
The lone Highlander atop the Glenfinnan Monument, situated on the edge of Loch Shiel, is just one of many sites that hikers, runners, and walkers may encounter along the West Highlands Way in Scotland. Following old military roads through pine forests and barren moorland, hikers trace centuries of lore while experiencing a taste of local life.
The¬†West Highland Way in Scotland stretches 96 miles across the Highlands from Milngavie to Fort William. Considered by many to be a moderate-to-difficult trail due to steep ascents and occasionally technical terrain, roughly 45,000 hikers attempt to complete the trail each year, with about the same number tackling individual stages or sections. As the country‚Äôs first and most popular waymarked trail, it has become a wildly important cornerst‚Ä¶

entry.title: The best ways to measure your fitness, according to science
entry.summary:
A woman folds into a standing forward bend, or uttanasana. Flexibility and joint mobility‚Äîkey elements of this pose‚Äîare among the most overlooked indicators of physical health. VO2 max? Mile time? Experts break down the most common health metrics and reveal which ones actually best reflect on your fitness at mid-life.
We count steps, track miles, and close our rings. Athletic metrics have infiltrated everything from viral #FitTok videos to biometric-tracking devices.
But when our devices remind us we haven‚Äôt hit our daily goal, experts say it might be time to question what those numbers really mean.¬†
‚ÄúIt's not so simple to just say, if you can do 20 push-ups and if you can run a 10 minute mile, you're good,‚Äù says Mathias Sorensen, an exercise physiologist at the UCSF Hum‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is there really an Ozempic baby boom?
entry.summary:
Developed for diabetes, GLP-1 drugs have become popular for weight loss. Researchers are investigating how they may influence fertility and pregnancy. These medications may be influencing fertility in ways scientists are only beginning to understand.
When the GLP-1 medications were first approved for weight loss, ‚ÄúI got pregnant on Ozempic‚Äù headlines quickly followed. People spoke about sudden unintended pregnancy, and ‚ÄúOzempic babies‚Äù entered the lexicon.
Could a medication meant to combat diabetes and shrink waistlines also boost fertility? For some, especially people struggling with infertility, these accounts sparked hope. For others, they raised new fears: Could these blockbuster drugs make birth control less effective?
The real story is not so simple. While anecdote‚Ä¶

entry.title: Doha: World Summit opens with pledge to speed social progress
entry.summary: The Second World Summit for Social Development opened in Doha on Tuesday with the adoption of the Doha Political Declaration ‚Äì a consensus pledge to accelerate action on poverty eradication, decent work and social inclusion, and to put the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) back on track.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Doha Social Summit: Path to fairer societies begins in the classroom
entry.summary: Education took centre stage on the opening day of the Second World Summit for Social Development in Doha, where leaders, educators and youth advocates underscored that learning is the foundation of inclusive and resilient societies.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Settler attacks in the West Bank, Madagascar hunger crisis, obesity in Europe
entry.summary: The UN humanitarian relief chief, Tom Fletcher, has sounded the alarm¬†over rising violence in the occupied West Bank, where attacks by Israeli settlers on Palestinians and their property continue to escalate.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Half of Jamaica‚Äôs population reeling from Hurricane Melissa
entry.summary: More than 1.5 million Jamaicans have been impacted by the devastation resulting from Hurricane Melissa, many losing their homes and livelihoods.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Potential Gaza stabilization force must have Security Council approval: Guterres
entry.summary: Any transition in Gaza must uphold unity with the West Bank and a two-State solution between Israelis and Palestinians, the UN Secretary-General said in Doha on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Famine declared in two Sudanese cities cut off by war, fragile gains elsewhere
entry.summary: New analysis of hunger and malnutrition in war-torn Sudan has revealed sharp contrasts along conflict lines, three UN agencies reported on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria‚Äôs future under threat from acute funding shortages
entry.summary: Hopes for a peaceful future in post-war Syria are at risk as funding for basic services dries up, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New climate pledges do little to correct global warming projection, UN warns
entry.summary: Available new climate pledges by governments have only slightly lowered global temperature rise over the course of this century, leaving the world on the path to a serious escalation of climate risks and damages.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Aid teams race to push back hunger; one million food parcels delivered
entry.summary: Food is slowly returning to the shelves in Gaza but supplies are still desperately inadequate, UN humanitarians said on Tuesday, as they issued fresh calls for wider access and continued financial support.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World leaders adopt Doha declaration to boost efforts on social development
entry.summary: Against a backdrop of escalating geopolitical tension and widening social divides, global leaders at the Second World Summit for Social Development on Tuesday adopted the Doha Political Declaration, signalling renewed resolve to advance justice and inclusion worldwide.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Around 224 million women still don‚Äôt access family planning
entry.summary: Since 1990, the number of people using modern contraception methods has doubled globally but despite this, nearly 224 million women in mainly developing regions still do not use safe and effective family planning methods, according to the UN sexual and reproductive health agency, UNFPA

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: LIVE from Doha: Second World Summit for Social Development
entry.summary: Leaders, policymakers and civil society representatives have gathered in Doha for the Second World Summit for Social Development, with the aim of renewing global commitments to inclusion, dignity and social justice. UN News is on the ground, bringing you live updates, key highlights and human stories from inside the conference halls and beyond. Follow this page for rolling coverage throughout the Summit. App users can follow the coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
